hints_html:
Since A is the matrix for the linear transformation then

\[\begin{aligned} T(\mathbf{e}_1)=A\mathbf{e}_1\end{aligned}\]

How can our knowledge from part(a) along with the fact that \(\mathbf{v}_1\), \(\mathbf{v}_2\), \(\mathbf{v}_3\) are eigenvectors help us?
hints_latex:
How can our knowledge from
{part(a)}
along with the fact that $\mathbf{v}_1$, $\mathbf{v}_2$, $\mathbf{v}_3$
are eigenvectors help us?
hints_raw:
Since A is the matrix for the linear transformation then

:<math>
T(\mathbf{e}_1)=A\mathbf{e}_1
</math>
How can our knowledge from [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2012/Question_3_(a)|part(a)]] along with the fact that <math>\mathbf{v}_1</math>, <math>\mathbf{v}_2</math>, <math>\mathbf{v}_3</math> are eigenvectors help us?
question: 3 (b)
sols_html:
The linear transformation acting on the vector \(\mathbf{e}_1\) will get given by

\[\begin{aligned} T(\mathbf{e}_1)=A\mathbf{e}_1.\end{aligned}\]

From part (a) we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{e}_1=\mathbf{v}_1-\mathbf{v}_2.\end{aligned}\]

In the question we are given the eigenvalues for these eigenvectors so we know

\[\begin{aligned} A\mathbf{v}_1&=1\mathbf{v}_1\\ A\mathbf{v}_2&=2\mathbf{v}_2\end{aligned}\]

Therefore

\[\begin{aligned} T(\mathbf{e}_1)=A\mathbf{e}_1=A\mathbf{v}_1-A\mathbf{v}_2=\mathbf{v}_1-2\mathbf{v}_2= \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1\\ -1 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
The linear transformation acting on the vector <math>\mathbf{e}_1</math> will get given by

:<math>
T(\mathbf{e}_1)=A\mathbf{e}_1.
</math>

From [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2012/Question_3_(a)|part (a)]] we have that

:<math>
\mathbf{e}_1=\mathbf{v}_1-\mathbf{v}_2.
</math>

In the question we are given the eigenvalues for these eigenvectors so we know

:<math>
\begin{align}
A\mathbf{v}_1&=1\mathbf{v}_1\\
A\mathbf{v}_2&=2\mathbf{v}_2
\end{align}
</math>

Therefore

:<math>
T(\mathbf{e}_1)=A\mathbf{e}_1=A\mathbf{v}_1-A\mathbf{v}_2=\mathbf{v}_1-2\mathbf{v}_2=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1\\
-1
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>
statement_html:
Let A be the matrix for the linear transformation T. Suppose we know that \(\mathbf{v}_1=\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\\1\end{bmatrix}\), \(\mathbf{v}_2=\begin{bmatrix}0\\1\\1\end{bmatrix}\), \(\mathbf{v}_3=\begin{bmatrix}1\\0\\1\end{bmatrix}\) are eigenvectors of A associated to the eigenvalues \(\lambda=1\), \(\lambda=2\), and \(\lambda=3\) respectively.

Calculate \(T(\mathbf{e}_1)\).
statement_latex:
Let A be the matrix for the linear transformation T. Suppose we know
that $\mathbf{v}_1=\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\\1\end{bmatrix}$,
$\mathbf{v}_2=\begin{bmatrix}0\\1\\1\end{bmatrix}$,
$\mathbf{v}_3=\begin{bmatrix}1\\0\\1\end{bmatrix}$ are eigenvectors of A
associated to the eigenvalues $\lambda=1$, $\lambda=2$, and $\lambda=3$
respectively.

Calculate $T(\mathbf{e}_1)$.
statement_raw:
Let A be the matrix for the linear transformation T.  Suppose we know that <math>\mathbf{v}_1=\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\\1\end{bmatrix}</math>, <math>\mathbf{v}_2=\begin{bmatrix}0\\1\\1\end{bmatrix}</math>, <math>\mathbf{v}_3=\begin{bmatrix}1\\0\\1\end{bmatrix}</math> are eigenvectors of A associated to the eigenvalues <math>\lambda=1</math>, <math>\lambda=2</math>, and <math>\lambda=3</math> respectively.

Calculate <math>T(\mathbf{e}_1)</math>.
